title: Episode 49 – Sally Ranney on Climate Week & Existential Risks
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
description: And we’ve published a podcast with her and she is encouraging all of us to engage and go to marchwithus.org to find out if you can get to New York great, if not there are marches occurring in virtually every major city.

[995.3s - 1005.7s]: So, when you look at the assumptions, I think we've been operating under false assumptions. We've been hypnotized by false assumptions for centuries.

[1006.6s - 1015.5s]: I wrote the forward to a book called The Trust Frequency by Connie Baxter, Marlow, and Andrew Cameron.

[1217.5s - 1219.7s]: I love it.

[1241.7s - 1245.3s]: And in Why on Earth, one of the chapters is called Think.

[1258.0s - 1268.7s]: So, stay tuned for that. But in this chapter called Think, we talk about the ecology of our thinking, and that we are influenced by all of these different impressions, conversations,

[1268.7s - 1275.0s]: media advertising, all kinds of things. And that ultimately, that is an ecosystem.

[1275.2s - 1278.9s]: We are responsible to steward, if we so choose.

[1279.7s - 1288.9s]: If we don't choose, we're going to be essentially hacked by other powers that want us to participate in certain economic ways, etc.

[1288.9s - 1293.8s]: And we see where that leads. We see plenty of examples of where that can lead us.

[1294.0s - 1315.1s]: But I think Sally implicit in this emergence of a more collaborative framework is a greater sense of personal, of individual responsibility and stewardship when it comes to examining and really understanding what our underlying assumptions.

[1315.1s - 1324.7s]: Yeah, exactly. Exactly. And most of us, take competition.

[1326.9s - 1340.3s]: Capitalism is really based on competition. I got to get mine first. I got to get to market first. I got to be smarter than the other guy. I got to have better PR. I have to have better social media, etc.

[1340.3s - 1354.5s]: And so, you know, that feeds more competition. Competition feeds competition. Love begets love. Abundance begets abundance.

[1354.9s - 1361.9s]: Scarcity begets scarcity. I don't know exactly how it works, but I know it works.

[1361.9s - 1370.2s]: You know, I've seen it in my own life. I've seen, I've seen it in other people's lives. I've seen it in other cultures.

[1371.5s - 1381.9s]: And you take the Kogi natives in Colombia, totally different system than we have.

[1381.9s - 1391.6s]: You know, no war, no police, no, you know, none of that because they have a different narrative. They have different assumptions.

[1667.9s - 1686.3s]: So that's, so we're moving into the climate week with a lot of the youth initiative and putting different people with different people that never would have happened before to support the youth.

[1687.0s - 1700.8s]: What comes out of that, I just want to take a minute to talk about the youth because they have been striking, you know, in the UK, in Sweden, in Germany, in Denmark.
